Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Religion and Empire, A Comparative Study of Inka and Spanish Imperialism in the Ayo Valley, Peru AD1000-1800

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Alexander Menaker, of the University of Texas-Austin, along with colleagues in Peru will carry out research examining how religion and ideology promote and legitimize imperial growth as well as investigating the effects of imperial expansion and colonial programs on local landscapes and populations. Although imperial ideologies claim absolute and universal authority, recent scholarship has emphasized the varied processes and relations through which states and empires attempt to exert control over people and territories outside of their geographic boundaries. Attending to the material conditions of life, archaeological research has illuminated the limits and local manifestations of states and empires, bringing into question written sources and absolute claims made by states and empires. Archaeology is poised to reconstruct local engagements with states and empires over the long-term, tracing the complex interactions among local and non-local state actors and populations, thus also challenging reductive binaries, such as, domination/resistance, European/Indigenous, and prehistoric/historic categorizations. This research demonstrates how the archaeological record along with multiple lines of evidence not only yields insight into local realities but also foregrounds productive approaches for investigating the experiences and conditions of local, often marginalized and indigenous, populations entangled among broader regional and global processes. This project promotes collaboration among local community members along with forming partnerships with Peruvian archaeologists and academics, with this project contributing to discussions of cultural heritage and encouraging local community involvement in considering and protecting materials of significant community importance. The research is of direct relevance to understanding contemporary issues of state maintenance and boundaries.

With this dissertation project, Mr. Menaker and his research team will conduct an archaeological and historical examination of Andagua and the Ayo Valley in the Southern Peruvian Andes, investigating the local cultural history and offering a comparative study of Inka and Spanish imperial strategies and effects in the region from AD1000-1800. Despite growing studies of the Inka there remain considerable gaps in research concerning Inka imperial expansion in the Southern Peruvian Andes, and while historical archaeology of Spanish colonialism in the Andes is currently a burgeoning field, few studies offer substantive comparative research of pre-Hispanic and Spanish imperial effects on a region. Historical accounts describe how the Inkas intensified local settlements and constructed new sites in the region, resettling populations to labor in administrative and ceremonial sites dedicated to sacred volcanoes and mountains. Constructed as a Spanish colonial reducci√≥n, with the forced resettlement of indigenous people, and surrounded by significant pre-Hispanic remains, the town of Andagua and the Ayo Valley present important natural and built features for investigating the extent of imperial statecraft in the area, yet the region has received no systematic archaeological attention and little academic research. This research offers a multi-scalar, long-term and comparative perspective of local occupations and cultural practices in the region during pre-Inka, Inka and Spanish rule, providing original data and research through using multiple archaeological field methods including, full coverage regional pedestrian and site-intensive surveys, systematic shovel test pits and 2x2m excavation units, and spatial mapping. Historical research will be conducted to provide insight into long-term regional processes that can be tested by archaeological evidence.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Andagua Valley in the Southern Peruvian Andes is a dynamic landscape composed of lava flows, volcanoes (scoria cones) and anthropogenic features (e.g. terraces and canals) that was subject to Inka and Spanish imperial reigns. Through archaeological, anthropological and historical research methods, this project investigated how states and empires attempt to incorporate and transform local landscapes and cultural practices in efforts to legitimize their social orders. This research has produced an invaluable collection of artifacts and data yielding foundational insight into cultural histories and local relations with expanding states and empires.

The project accomplished its key objectives for research, most principally, successfully carrying out the first systematic archaeological research in the Andagua Valley. The primary phase involved the completion of systematic regional pedestrian survey (45km2 area) with the project registering 97 archaeological sites as well as documenting varying features and artifacts that traverse a range of human occupations. Subsequently, the project carried out 10 test-pit excavations at 6 distinct archaeological sites identified during survey (1x1m and 2x2m units, 32m2 total area excavated). In addition, the project completed comprehensive artifact analysis of more than 17,000 artifacts recovered during all phases of fieldwork. The project performed aerial photography and mapping with an unmanned aerial vehicle of 6 archaeological sites to document and produce maps of settlement patterns and features. Oral histories were collected from local community members, offering specific familial histories and local interpretations and knowledges, such as local origin myths, toponyms and property histories. Research resulted in the first archaeological collection to produce detailed ceramic sequences and typologies in the valley, along with documenting associated diagnostic features (architecture, paths, etc.). For instance, surface collections of ceramic artifacts included the recovery of the ceramic type exemplifying the Soporo style, which had been characterized as similar to Formative style ceramics (approx. BC 1500 – AD 500) and one of the few styles previously identified in the valley (Neira Avendaño 1998; Menaker and Falcon Huayta 2016). The recurring presence of the Soporo ceramic style throughout the valley in association with archaeological sites composed of multiple occupations is indicative of the deep pre-Hispanic pasts that have shaped the Southern Peruvian Andes.

Archaeological research in the valley further illuminates the tensions of empires evident in local settlement patterns and cultural practices and material culture, such as, stone offerings and monoliths (huancas), and ceramics among others that were marginalized and maintained during Inka and Spanish colonial rule, from AD1000 to 1800. In addition to the construction of the contemporary town of Andagua as a Spanish colonial reducción (which involved the forced resettlement of indigenous people to nucleated settlements), the town consists of multiple, overlapping occupations with our archaeological research distinguishing local pre-Inka and non-Inka practices from Inka contexts. The project identified a previously undocumented pre-Inka and Inka occupation that is located in the Southeastern section of the contemporary town of Andagua (commonly known as Andagua Antiguo, or “Old Andagua”). While the project had hypothesized some pre-Hispanic and Inka presence was associated with the town, the extent of the occupation that the project revealed exceeded expectations and offers critical data for the region. In Andagua, Inka imperial statecraft sought to re-orient local populations’ relations with the landscape, shifting from local huancas and ritual locations in the southern edge of the contemporary town of Andagua, to emphasizing volcanic flows in the broader valley with the placement of an ushnu (ceremonial platform associated with greater density of artifacts), and which now has a chapel for the Virgen de Asuncion set atop (and located at the edge of the colonial reducción), exemplifying Spanish colonialism’s subsequent and enduring effects. Research in the Andagua Valley has shown how although imperial ideologies claim absolute and universal authority, they are incomplete and become entangled with local practices and the stubborn materiality of history.

Broader impacts of the project involved engaging and collaborating with local community stakeholders of Andagua, including consulting with Andagua community members on developing a local heritage museum, as well as, providing opportunities for professional training for Peruvian, American and international students. The project offered several detailed presentations to share the project’s research methods and results with the local community of Andagua, local school students and Peruvian university students and academics. Representatives of the project also attended multiple TV and radio interviews on local radio stations in Andagua and in Arequipa sharing knowledge of the project’s research and results. Technical reports have been provided to the local community and associated publications will be provided to the local community and made available to scholars and broader audiences when completed. The project has raised critical awareness of the local cultural histories of the Andagua Valley as well as building foundational ground for collaboration with local stakeholders and continued maintenance and education of local cultural heritage.
